articles.title: About Me
articles.contents:
About Me
My Name is Noel Jung and I am a Bachelor of Health Sciences Student
at Queens University. I enjoy swimming and reading. This is my first
experience coding in R and in data science.
Email: noeljjung@gmail.com
About the Project
My final project investigates if changes in an increase in
temperature is correlated with an increase in the number of West Nile
and Lyme Disease cases. More about this topic can be seen on the home
page. I chose this project because I wanted to pursue this topic for an
old project, however I lacked the skill to conduct it properly. I wanted
to try again with this website and with my newfound skills in coding and
data science.
Link to my Github
Repository for my Wesbite
https://github.com/NoelJung/Temperature-and-Vector-Diseases
Credits
I learned how to code in R through Dr. David Kane’s data science
course. The website to the course can be found here:
https://bootcamp.davidkane.info/

Sources
2022-07-07




The Centre of Disease Control (CDC) is a government run organization
that collects data and monitors health concerns for the nation including
pathogens, foods and more. Its goal is to control the spread of
infectious diseases and promote health for all.
You can learn more about the CDC on their website at https://www.cdc.gov/. (CDC?)

articles.title: The Effect of Temperature on Vector Borne Diseases
articles.description: A website on the effects of changing temperature on the spread of Vector Borne Diseases
articles.contents:
Introduction
West Nile and Lyme Disease are both examples of vector borne
diseases. Vector borne diseases are diseases that are transmitted by the
bite of an infected animal. Specifically for West Nile and Lyme, a
mosquito bite and a tick bite respectively are capable of transmitting
the virus into a human host to cause the disease.
However, both mosquitoes and ticks are sensitive to their
environment. Specifically, changing temperature can change how well
mosquitoes or ticks are able to survive and thrive. This changes the
number of active mosquitoes or ticks that can transmit these viruses,
thus impacting the number of cases that appear. In this website, I will
try to explore this relationship by comparing annual average
temperatures the number of cases of each disease in the US.
West Nile Disease
West Nile Disease is spread by mosquito bites. Specifically for
mosquitoes, higher temperatures creates optimal conditions for them to
thrive, allowing them to:
Remain active for more parts of the year
Develop at a faster rate to reach full adulthood
These conditions allow mosquitoes to proliferate earlier and for
longer periods of time. This gives mosquitoes more opportunities to
spread the West Nile Virus, thus increasing the number of cases.



Of course, this is how this is supposed to work on paper. In reality,
there are a multitude of other variables that are contribute to how well
mosquitoes are able to transmit West Nile, something which can be seen
and is explained in the West Nile Disease section of this website.
Lyme Disease
Comparatively, Lyme Disease is spread by tick bites. While higher
temperatures are great for mosquitoes, they are not ideal for ticks.
Specifically, the black-legged tick, the type of tick that spreads Lyme
Disease, high temperatures cause them to become less active as they
prefer cooler temperatures, typically between 4 and 25 degrees Celsius
(39.2 to 77 degrees Fahrenheit).



Therefore, higher temperatures can both be beneficial and detrimental
for ticks. Higher temperatures in cold areas, can create a climate ideal
for ticks to survive thus increasing their ability to spread Lyme
Disease. However higher temperatures in warm areas can create overly hot
climates that can reduce tick activity, reducing their ability to spread
Lyme Disease.
Again however, this is only how it works on paper. In reality, other
variables are also at play which change how well ticks are able to
thrive in a given area, something which can be seen and is explained in
the Lyme Disease section of this website.

Lyme Disease





Introduction
As stated in the home page, higher temperatures can improve tick
activity, however climates that are too hot reduce it. The optimal
temperature for ticks is about 4 and 25 degrees Celsius (39.2 to 77
degrees Fahrenheit). As a result, on paper it is expected that as
temperatures warm to get within this range, tick activity would increase
thus increasing the number of Lyme Disease cases. If conditions get too
hot to exit this range, tick activity would decrease reducing the number
of Lyme Disease cases.
This of course is not at all what is actually seen in the graphs
below. Similar to the West Nile Disease graphs, the CDC only had data
from 2010 to 2019, meaning only these years were considered. Annual
average temperature data was collected from the NOAA and annual number
of Lyme Disease cases were collected from the CDC. The relationship
between these two variables was investigated in the three states with
the highest number of Lyme Disease cases, Pennsylvania, New York and New
Jersey, and at a national level as well. Through these graphs we can see
that the effect of temperature on Lyme Disease cases varies wildly!
#Images

include_graphics("images/PenLy.png")

include_graphics("images/NewJLy.png")

include_graphics("images/NewYLy.png")

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) collects
data on weather patterns, monitors the climate and provides support for
environmental protection and restoration. Their goal is better
understand the natural world and help protect it using science.
You can learn more about the NOAA on their website at https://www.noaa.gov/about-our-agency.
(NOAA?)

articles.title: Other Variables
articles.description: Why does temperature not have the effect as predicted on vector borne diseases?
articles.contents:
Why does temperature not affect the number of West Nile and Lyme
disease cases as expected? Mainly because there are a multitude of other
factors at play that also affect how well these diseases can
proliferate.
Factors
Affecting How Well Ticks and Mosquitoes Can Infect People
While temperature is a crucial factor to how well ticks and
mosquitoes can thrive, there are other factors to consider such as:
Precipitation
Ticks prefer humid environments and mosquitoes need wet areas to lay
eggs and reproduce
Precipitation levels can thus change the population of ticks and
mosquitoes in a given area meaning the rate at which ticks and
mosquitoes can transmit West Nile or Lyme Disease is affected

Human Behaviour
Wearing bug spray, long sleeves and pants, or just staying inside
are all ways humans limit the ability of ticks and mosquitoes to bite
and transmit West Nile or Lyme Disease

Population Density
Ticks generally remain in wooded, forest areas and mosquitoes
typically remain in areas where there is lots of stagnant water to lay
eggs
If there is a lack of people around these areas, the rate at which
ticks and mosquitoes can bite and thus transmit West Nile or Lyme
Disease changes

Factors
Affecting How Well West Nile and Lyme Disease Can Proliferate
One other factor we have not considered is the way West Nile Disease
or Lyme Disease can infect a mosquito or tick in the first place.
Mosquitoes typically become infected with West Nile Disease from
birds. Specifically, if they feed from a bird that has West Nile Disease
in its blood, the virus will transmit to the mosquito. If that mosquito
then bites a human, the virus can then transmit to the person thus
causing West Nile Disease.



Figure 1: Graphic Showing how the West Nile Virus Transfers
from Bird to Mosquito to Human
The process in which ticks get infected is much the same. There is no
specific animal that ticks can contract the bacteria causing Lyme
Disease from, however if it bites onto an infected animal, the bacteria
can latch to the tick. If the tick then bites a human, the bacteria can
infect that person causing Lyme Disease.
However, changing conditions can affect how well mosquitoes and ticks
are able to feed off of infected animals in the first place. For example
in the case of West Nile disease, the most common type of bird that
mosquitoes become infected from are birds from the Passeriforme order.
Changing temperatures, precipitation and habitat conditions can result
in changes to migratory patters, wintering groups and general behaviour
of these birds. This changes the presence of Passeriforme birds in a
given area, thus affecting how well a mosquito is able to become
infected with West Nile to spread in the first place.



Figure 2: Picture of Common Passeriforme Birds
By preventing ticks or mosquitoes from becoming infected in the first
place, changing conditions can affect how well West Nile or Lyme Disease
is able to spread to people.
Therefore, in reality there are a multitude of other variables at
play that affect how well ticks and mosquitoes are able to spread Lyme
and West Nile Disease respectively. While temperature certainly does
play a role, it is only one part of the puzzle and there are other
factors to consider.

West Nile Disease





Introduction
As stated on the home page, higher temperatures would be expected to
cause a higher number of West Nile disease cases as they allow
mosquitoes to become more prevalent. However, this is not supported by
the trends shown in the graphs below.
The graphs below use average annual temperature data collected by the
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration against the annual
number of West Nile disease cases. The CDC contained West Nile Disease
data from 1999 to 2020, meaning only these years were considered. The
annual temperature and case numbers were compared in the states of
California, Colorado and Texas as they had the top three highest number
of West Nile cases. A comparison between the national annual temperature
the national annual number of West Nile cases was also made in a final,
fourth graph. Through these graphs we can see that the relationship
between temperature and West Nile cases is not as simplistic as it is on
paper!
#Images
